standard_metadata.standard_description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Multiply whole numbers and decimals less than 1

hints.content: There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}18\times 0.4\\\\ &=18 \times 4 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &= 72 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=7.2 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $18\times 4=72$  The decimal $0.4$ is a little less than half. Half of $18$ is $9$, so $18\times 0.4$ is a little less than $9$.  $18\times 0.4=7.2$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{18}\times\greenD{0.4}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{18}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{4}{10}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{18} \times \greenD{4}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{72}{10}\\\\ &=7.2 \end{align}$
###The answer  $7.2=18 \times 0.4$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}8\times 0.2\\\\ &=8\times 2 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &= 16 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=1.6 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $8\times 2=16$  The decimal $0.2$ is a little less than a fourth. A fourth of $8$ is $2$, so $8\times 0.2$ is a little less than $2$.  $8\times 0.2=1.6$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{8}\times\greenD{0.2}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{8}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{2}{10}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{8} \times \greenD{2}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{16}{10}\\\\ &=1.6 \end{align}$
###The answer  $1.6=8 \times 0.2$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.4\times 9\\\\ &=4\text{ tenths}\times9\\\\ &= 36  \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=3.6 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $4\times9=36$  The decimal $0.4$ is a little less than half. Half of $9$ is $4.5$, so $0.4\times 9$ is a little less than $4.5$.  $0.4\times 9=3.6$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.4}\times\greenD{9}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{4}{10}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{9}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{4} \times \greenD{9}}{\blueD{10} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{36}{10}\\\\ &=3.6 \end{align}$
###The answer  $3.6=0.4 \times 9$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.7\times 64\\\\ &=7\text{ tenths}\times64\\\\ &= 448  \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=44.8 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $7\times64=448$  The decimal $0.7$ is more than half. Half of $64$ is $32$, so $0.7\times 64$ is more than $32$.  $0.7\times 64=44.8$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.7}\times\greenD{64}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{64}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{7} \times \greenD{64}}{\blueD{10} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{448}{10}\\\\ &=44.8 \end{align}$
###The answer  $44.8=0.7 \times 64$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.8\times 17\\\\ &=8\text{ tenths}\times17\\\\ &= 136  \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=13.6 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $8\times17=136$  The decimal $0.8$ is a little less than $1$. $17$ times $1$ is $17$, so $0.8\times 17$ is a little less than $17$.  $0.8\times 17=13.6$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.8}\times\greenD{17}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{17}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{8} \times \greenD{17}}{\blueD{10} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{136}{10}\\\\ &=13.6 \end{align}$
###The answer  $0.8 \times 17 = 13.6$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}3\times 0.6\\\\ &=3 \times 6 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &= 18 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=1.8 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $3\times 6=18$  The decimal $0.6$ is a little more than half. Half of $3$ is $1.5$, so $3\times 0.6$ is a little more than $1.5$.  $3\times 0.6=1.8$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{3}\times\greenD{0.6}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{3}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{6}{10}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{3} \times \greenD{6}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{18}{10}\\\\ &=1.8 \end{align}$
###The answer  $3 \times 0.6 = 1.8$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}19\times 0.3\\\\ &=19\times 3 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &= 57 \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=5.7 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $19\times3=57$  The decimal $0.3$ is a little more than a fourth. A fourth of $19$ is about $5$, so $19\times 0.3$ is a little more than $5$.  $19\times 0.3=5.7$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{19}\times\greenD{0.3}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{19}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{19} \times \greenD{3}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{57}{10}\\\\ &=5.7 \end{align}$
###The answer  $19 \times 0.3 = 5.7$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of tenths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.9\times 9\\\\ &=9\text{ tenths}\times9\\\\ &= 81  \text{ tenths}\\\\ &=8.1 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $9\times9=81$  The decimal $0.9$ is almost $1$. $9$ times $1$ is $9$, so $0.9\times 9$ is almost $9$.  $0.9\times 9=8.1$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.9}\times\greenD{9}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{9}{10}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{9}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{9} \times \greenD{9}}{\blueD{10} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{81}{10}\\\\ &=8.1 \end{align}$
###The answer  $0.9 \times 9 = 8.1$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}3\times 0.25\\\\ &=3\times25\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 75\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=0.75 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $3\times25=75$  The value $0.25$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{4}$.  $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of $3$ is between $0$ and $1$, so $3\times 0.25$ is between $0$ and $1$.  $3\times 0.25=0.75$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{3}\times\greenD{0.25}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{3}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{25}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{3} \times \greenD{25}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{75}{100}\\\\ &=0.75 \end{align}$
###The answer  $3 \times 0.25 = 0.75$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}5\times 0.25\\\\ &=5\times25\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 125\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=1.25 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $5\times25=125$  The value $0.25$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{4}$.  $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of $5$ is between $1$ and $2$, so $5\times 0.25$ is between $1$ and $2$.  $5\times 0.25=1.25$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{5}\times\greenD{0.25}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{5}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{25}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{5} \times \greenD{25}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{125}{100}\\\\ &=1.25 \end{align}$
###The answer  $1.25=5 \times 0.25$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}7\times 0.25\\\\ &=7\times25\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 175\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=1.75 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $7\times25=175$  The value $0.25$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{4}$.  $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of $7$ is between $1$ and $2$, so $7\times 0.25$ is between $1$ and $2$.  $7\times 0.25=1.75$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{7}\times\greenD{0.25}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{7}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{25}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{7} \times \greenD{25}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{175}{100}\\\\ &=1.75 \end{align}$
###The answer  $7 \times 0.25 = 1.75$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.25\times15\\\\ &=25\text{ hundredths}\times15\\\\ &= 375\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=3.75 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $25\times15=375$  The value $0.25$ is equal to $\dfrac{1}{4}$.  $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of $15$ is between $3$ and $4$, so $0.25\times15$ is between $3$ and $4$.  $0.25\times15=3.75$
###The answer  $3.75=0.25 \times 15$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}9\times 0.75\\\\ &=9\times75\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 675\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=6.75 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $9\times75=675$  The value $0.75$ is equal to $\dfrac{3}{4}$.  $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $9$ is between $6$ and $7$, so $9\times 0.75$ is between $6$ and $7$.  $9\times 0.75=6.75$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{9}\times\greenD{0.75}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{9}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{75}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{9} \times \greenD{75}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{675}{100}\\\\ &=6.75 \end{align}$
###The answer  $9 \times 0.75 = 6.75$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}12\times 0.75\\\\ &=12\times75\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 900\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=9 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $12\times75=900$  The value $0.75$ is equal to $\dfrac{3}{4}$.  $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $12$ is $9$, so $12\times 0.75$ is $9$.  $12\times 0.75=9$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{12}\times\greenD{0.75}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{12}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{75}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{12} \times \greenD{75}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{900}{100}\\\\ &=9 \end{align}$
###The answer  $9 = 12 \times0.75$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.75\times 5\\\\ &=75\text{ hundredths}\times5\\\\ &= 375\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=3.75 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $0.75\times5=375$  The value $0.75$ is equal to $\dfrac{3}{4}$.  $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $5$ is between $3$ and $4$, so $0.75\times 5$ is between $3$ and $4$.  $0.75\times 5=3.75$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.75}\times\greenD{5}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{75}{100}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{5}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{75} \times \greenD{5}}{\blueD{100} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{375}{100}\\\\ &=3.75 \end{align}$
###The answer  $0.75 \times 5 = 3.75$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see three ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.75\times6\\\\ &=75\text{ hundredths}\times6\\\\ &= 450\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=4.5 \end{align}$

###Estimation strategy  We can multiply the digits, then use estimation to place the decimal point.  $0.75\times6=450$  The value $0.75$ is equal to $\dfrac{3}{4}$.  $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $6$ is between $4$ and $5$, so $0.75\times 6$ is between $4$ and $5$.  $0.75\times 6=4.5$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.75}\times\greenD{6}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{75}{100}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{6}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{75} \times \greenD{6}}{\blueD{100} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{450}{100}\\\\ &=4.5 \end{align}$
###The answer  $4.5=0.75 \times 6 $
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see two ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}3\times 0.52\\\\ &=3\times52\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 156\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=1.56 \end{align}$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{3}\times\greenD{0.52}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{3}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{52}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{3} \times \greenD{52}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{156}{100}\\\\ &=1.56 \end{align}$
###The answer  $3 \times 0.52 = 1.56$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see two ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}37\times 0.76\\\\ &=37\times76\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 2{,}812\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=28.12 \end{align}$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{37}\times\greenD{0.76}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{37}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{76}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{37} \times \greenD{76}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{2{,}812}{100}\\\\ &=28.12 \end{align}$
###The answer  $28.12=37 \times 0.76$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{4}\times\greenD{0.43}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{4}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{43}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{4} \times \greenD{43}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{172}{100}\\\\ &=1.72 \end{align}$
###The answer  $4 \times 0.43 = 1.72$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see two ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}7\times 0.86\\\\ &=7\times86\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &= 602\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=6.02 \end{align}$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{7}\times\greenD{0.86}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{7}{1}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{86}{100}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{7} \times \greenD{86}}{\blueD{1} \times \greenD{100}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{602}{100}\\\\ &=6.02 \end{align}$
###The answer  $6.02=7 \times 0.86$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see two ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.58\times15\\\\ &=58\text{ hundredths}\times15\\\\ &= 870\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=8.7 \end{align}$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.58}\times\greenD{15}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{58}{100}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{15}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{58} \times \greenD{15}}{\blueD{100} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{870}{100}\\\\ &=8.7 \end{align}$
###The answer  $0.58 \times 15 = 8.7$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see two ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.12\times5\\\\ &=12\text{ hundredths}\times5\\\\ &= 60\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=0.6 \end{align}$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.12}\times\greenD{5}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{12}{100}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{5}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{12} \times \greenD{5}}{\blueD{100} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{60}{100}\\\\ &=0.6 \end{align}$

There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see two ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.14\times80\\\\ &=14\text{ hundredths}\times80\\\\ &= 1{,}120\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=11.2 \end{align}$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.14}\times\greenD{80}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{14}{100}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{80}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{14} \times \greenD{80}}{\blueD{100} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{1{,}120}{100}\\\\ &=11.2 \end{align}$
###The answer  $0.14 \times 80 = 11.2$
There are many ways to solve this problem. Let's see two ways we could multiply.
###Place value strategy  We can think in terms of hundredths:  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}0.64\times3\\\\ &=64\text{ hundredths}\times3\\\\ &= 192\text{ hundredths}\\\\ &=1.92 \end{align}$

###Fraction multiplication strategy  Decimals are a kind of fraction, so we can use fraction multiplication.  $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{0.64}\times\greenD{3}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{64}{100}} \times \greenD{\dfrac{3}{1}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\blueD{64} \times \greenD{3}}{\blueD{100} \times \greenD{1}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{192}{100}\\\\ &=1.92 \end{align}$
###The answer  $1.92 = 0.64 \times 3$
